title: Children are watching twice as much online video as four years ago as they abandon TV
text:
The number of young Americans watching online videos daily has more than doubled in the past few years according survey findings released Tuesday.

The app of choice is overwhelmingly YouTube, which is supposedly off limits for children under the age of 13.

The survey was conducted by Common Sense Media, a non-profit organization that tracks young people's media trends, and is a follow up to their 2015 survey.

After surveying 1,677 young people between the ages of eight and 18, Common Sense Media learned that the rate children watch online videos has doubled in just four years.

Pictured: a graph showing the stark increase of American kids who watch online videos 'every day' over the past four years

56 percent of eight to 12-year-olds watch online videos every day and 69 percent of 13 to 18-year-olds have the same habit.

In 2015 those numbers were 24 percent and 34 percent, respectively.

'It really is the air they breathe,' said Michael Robb, senior director of research for Common Sense Media.

The amount of time children and teens spend watching online content has grown from around a half-hour a day to an average of one hour a day.

However, overall screen time hasn't changed all that much.

Tweens, ages eight to 12, spend four hours and 44 minutes per day watching entertainment media.

Teens clocked in at seven hours and 22 minutes.

Tweens are looking at screens more than four hours a day and the number turns to seven when it comes to teenagers

Although parents may attribute some of these hours to educational use, the survey notes that these times exclude homework, reading books or listening to music.

These findings do more than illustrate the rise of streaming devices, usually smartphones, tablets, and laptops, among you people.

They also show the slow, but steady fall of traditional television.

The percentage of tweens who say they like watching TV 'a lot' has dropped from 61 percent to 50 percent, while the numbers for teens lowered from 45 percent to 33 percent.

The familiar pastime of watching TV as a family, oftentimes used as a way to bond, is gradually being pushed out.

Robb said: 'I think there is something lost in losing even that kind of shared family experience.'

According to the study, tweens and teens would rather be on YouTube.

Even three-quarters of tweens, who are not old enough for the site's age restriction, flock to the video-sharing platform.

The survey found that tween and teens prefer to use online video-sharing sites like YouTube instead of traditional TV

Only 23 percent of tweens say they watch YouTube Kids, a separate video service aimed at children with curated selections of content and parental control features.

After the findings were released, YouTube said they will share details about ways the company is thinking to approach children and families.

Perks of screen time for adolescents As much as parents worry about their children’s internet and social media presence, studies find that these platforms are not all bad. The American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry say some benefits are: Staying connected to friends

Meeting new friends with shared interests

Finding community and support for specific activities

Sharing art work or music

Exploring and expressing themselves

Farshad Shadloo, a spokesperson for YouTube, doubled down on the company's terms of use.

'YouTube is not a site for people under 13.'

It's unsurprising that young Americans are also consumed by smart phones, but the age at which they're getting their first phone is shocking.

About one in five kids received their first handset at age eight.

By age 11, 53 percent of children have a phone and more than two-thirds have a device by age 12.

Robb said: 'That's eye-opening. That's a lot of responsibility for a little kid.'

The responsibility also falls on the parents.

'It puts a lot of pressure on a parent to figure out what they can reasonably filter,' Robb said.

Only 23 percent of children say tweens say they watch YouTube Kids, a streaming service dedicated to users under 13, despite the regular YouTube app having an age restriction

Sarah Domoff, an assistant professor of clinical psychology at Central Michigan University studies technology's impact on families and children.

She thinks parents are overwhelmed.

'It's really hard to block out certain things unless you're really standing over your child,' she said.

This is especially true in an era where many devices are handheld and portable.

Domoff said some parents could do more in terms of tracking screen time, but service filters on platforms like YouTube also aren't sufficient.

Critics are wary of how much YouTube will actually do to curb children's app usage when the site flourishes on users going down 'rabbit holes' of content.

Robb said: 'If your model is built on maintaining attention, it's really hard to do something.'

He suggests families combat screen time in a variety of ways.

'Protect homework time, family time, dinner time and bed time. Have device-free times or zones.'

Domoff said: 'There needs to be a game plan.
description: Common Sense Media conducted a survey that found that young American  have doubled the amount of time they spend watching online videos and that YouTube is the platform of choice
